feed.title: mlops.systems
feed.subtitle: A place to share my technical learnings.

entry.title: Writing Code
entry.summary: I read Daniel Roy Greenfeld’s post on how he found that coding a lot was key to improving his skills. It makes sense. Everything I’ve read so far and my previous experience at the metaskill of learning new things tells me that it is a good investment of time.

entry.title: Reading Python Code
entry.summary: It’s a truism of sorts that in order to improve your skills, you have to practice them. For coding, the stereotypical image is of someone typing, actually creating new things. But as often as not, you’re going to be reading code instead. This code might be something you write yesterday or last year, or it might be something that someone else wrote.

entry.title: A Baseline Python Development Setup
entry.summary: The world of Python versioning (and the downstream package versioning) is wild. This StackOverflow thread gives you a sense of some of the core issues at play. (As an indication of the importance of the issue, even BDFL Guido van Rossum himself has the current second most upvoted answer.)

entry.title: Six problems TFX was trying to solve in 2017

link.title: Six problems TFX was trying to solve in 2017

entry.summary: TensorFlow Extended or TFX is a platform for machine learning that claims to handle pretty much everything you’d need for end-to-end model training, deployment and retraining. It was developed for Google, the successor to Sibyl, and released in public in 2017. I read the original paper that accompanied its release to understand the problems it was trying to solve, as well as to get a handle on the specific context in which it was developed. (It’s worth being wary about tools developed at places like Google; after all, hardly any of us are operating at Google-scale).
